numbered_ace_sentences: 1. Admissions spike for the top 0.1% of students.
2. This spike happens regardless of a student's legacy status.
3. Some students are poorer students.
4. For poorer students, the admission gap between legacy applicants and non-legacy applicants is fairly stable.
5. Some applicants are above the 50th percentile.
6. For applicants above the 50th percentile, legacy students have a much higher advantage than non-legacy students.
7. The admittance of non-legacy students dips after the 70th percentile.
8. The admittance of non-legacy students spikes again around the 99th percentile.
9. Non-legacy students have the best admittance if they are above the 90th percentile.
10. Non-legacy students have the best admittance if they are below the 50th percentile.
11. Some students are upper-class students.
12. Some students are middle-class students.
13. Upper-class students and middle-class students do not have great chances unless they are legacy students.
14. The author thinks that this is because these students are not in need of financial aid.
15. The author thinks that this is because these students are not willing or able to fund programs.
16. The author asks what factors are considered other than test scores and legacy status and parental income.
17. The author asks how extracurricular activities and GPA and other factors would change this.
18. Many schools no longer consider test scores.
19. Many elite colleges are schools.
20. Many elite colleges no longer consider test scores.
21. The author is a high school student.
22. The author is anxious about college admissions.
23. The author has seen many people with impressive applications.
24. Many of these people were not accepted into the schools that they wanted.
25. The author knows a person personally.
26. This person graduated from high school in 2022.
27. This person had good grades.
28. This person had great test scores.
29. This person spent a year in an exchange program.
30. This person still got in almost nowhere she applied.
31. The headline is: No Legacy, No Money, No Luck: Bias in College Admissions.
